TopicTitle: How many things have you lost because hitting the "End Flight" button?

Articles.Content:
Title says it all.

Biggest thing i've lost because of it was my Duna lander or my space station.

Damn you End Flight!

Lost huge space stations... A Mun base and a huge interplanetary train I built up out of about 12 launches... I was just tired and hit End Flight instead of Space Centre.

Another naughty design error is the "New" in the VAB. I had a really nice payload I had put together and balanced the RCS and then I went and hit the NEW button instead of hitting the Subassembly button (I just wanted one of my prebuilt boosters) and "POOF!"... gone...

the subassmbly loader vs new craft thing has bothered me for a while.

but now 0.20 solved the problem.
There's a plugin which blocks the end flight button.
It's actually never happened to me. I am always careful when hitting the buttons of than "End Flight."

My sanity... After losing a station that took about 25 launches to construct.

I learned one valuable lesson from that...

are you calling the end flight button a design error? you do realize you have to confirm the end flight? how many clicks do you think is enough then to not accidentally end flights? imo it's fine, i mean i have accidentally ended flights that were not to be ended, but its my fault, not a design error, not a bug nor any other fault of the software, just a stupid user error.

Don't know how many (a lot) but the biggest thing I lost was a station that took at least one or two dozen flights.

Two ways to recover from an accidental 'End Flight':

1: [alt]+[F4] ASAP to totally kill KSP before it gets the chance to update your persistent file.

2: [F9] to load your latest quicksafe. Unless you manually quicksaved this will reset you to the moment of your latest launch.

If you're really worried about it, do what I did and teach yourself the habit of hitting F5 before leaving a flight whether to end it or just switch to another mission. That way, you could undo an end flight if you ever did do one by mistake.
